text:
54-56 West 40th Street, south side, east of 6th Avenue, showing the church structure that is to be replaced with the present Republican Club Building.
Note the Bryant Park fence in tho foreground.
Prior to 1902
Gift of Urbrock Collection

110, 112 West 40th Street, south side, west of Sixth Avenue.
About 1911.

(1) Bryant Park: A view westward of same, as seen from the rear of the New York Public Library Building and showing the lawn, being resodded. Buildings in the background are on the west side of Sixth Ave., from West 40th (left) to 42nd (right) Streets.

1936.
New York Public Library

(2) The same view at an earlier date, prior to the removal of the fountain to the western side of the Park. Note in the background the Bush Terminal Annex under construction.

1916.
Nicholas Savostayanoff.
Gift of George D. Chinn.

American Radiator Building.
April 30, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

Sixth Avenue, east side, north from W. 40th Street, showing the westerly extremity of Bryant Park. Buildings in the background are on the north side of 42nd Street, and extend eastward towards Fifth Avenue. The low center unit is Stern's Department store. Reconstruction work in the Park was disturbed by the 6th Avenue subway construction. Restoration after same occurred in 1940.
View 1: August 20, 1934
View 2: June 7, 1934
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS

Sixth Avenue, east side, north from W. 40th Street, showing the westerly extremity of Bryant Park. Buildings in the background are on the north side of 42nd Street, and extend eastward towards Fifth Avenue. The low center unit is Stern's Department store. Reconstruction work in the Park was disturbed by the 6th Avenue subway construction. Restoration after same occurred in 1940.
View 1: August 20, 1934
View 2: June 7, 1934
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS

Bryant Park, looking west from the rear of the New York Public Library, and showing the Park being drastically remodeled, under the regime of Park Commissioner Robert Moses. The remarkable thing about this job was the small size of the budget allowed for it and
the results accomplished nonetheless.
April 25, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, from the roof of the Public Library, on the 42nd Street side, showing the Park under reconstruction.

(1)
Sixth Ave., east side, north from, but not including West 40th., to and including 42nd Streets. Shown on the right, is Bryant Park. Men working, are placing a sheet wall on the western side of said park, to protect underground aqueduct, in preparation for the excavation for the new Municipal Sixth Ave., subway.

May 8, 1936.

Mr. Schwartz.
New York Public Library.

(2)
The same, showing a more inclusive view. Notice the Sixth Ave., Elevated and Station at West 42nd Street. This structure will be shored up during construction of subway and eventually demolished.

May 8, 1936.

Mr. Schwartz.
New York Public Library.

(3)
The same, but viewed southward.

May 8, 1936.

Mr. Schwartz.
New York Public Library.

Bryant Park: An eastward view across same, from Sixth Ave. (foreground) between West 40th (right) and 42nd (left) Streets, showing the rear of the Central Building of the New York Public Library which faces on the west side of Fifth Ave., as photographed at dusk (7 P.M.). Across the low roof of the aforementioned educational institution are the spires of the Chrysler, Lincoln, News, Lefcourt-Colonial, New York Trust
Company, and No. 10 East 40th Street Buildings.
March 17, 1938.
Mr. Nathan Schwartz.
New York Public Library.

Sixth Avenue, at W. 40th Street showing one of the last stages oI the Sixth Avenue "El" demolition. Simultaneous with this civic project is the subway construction underground. The latter is eividenced by the temporary wood planking. The photographer is viewing northeastward and towards Bryant Park, the New York Public Library and W. 42nd Street Buildings. Vaguely apparent at the upper right are the Lincoln and the Chrysler
Buildinge.
April 4, 1939
Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library
Neg A I379

Sixth Avenue, at W. 40th Street, (right) showing "El" demolition at this point. The photographer is viewing northeastward and shows across Bryant Park, buildings on the north side of W. 42nd Street between this thoroughfare and Fifth Avenue. From left to right these are: Sterns Department Store, the former Aeolian Hall, the Salmon Tower and No. 500 Fifth Avenue. Nestling beneath the latter is a wing of the New York Public Library.

April 4, 1939
Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library

Sixth Avenue, at W. 40th Street (right), showing "El" demolition, Bryant Park, and the rear of the New YYork Public Library. To the left of the latter is the towering office building, Nv. 500 Fifth Avenue. Adjacent to same is the Salmon Tower Building. Outlined at the upper right are the Lincoln and the Chrysler BuilUings. Note the wood planking under foot that covers over subway construction. This activity is being conducted simultaneously with the Sixth Avenue "El"
demolition.
April 4, 1939
Mr. Nathan Schwartzz
New Iork Public Library

Bryant Park: The snow covered lawn as
viewed westward from the rear nf the New York Public Library. ~Sixth Avenue forms the westerly edge, with West 40th Stre t on the left, and 42nd Street on the right. Note the absence of the Sixth Avenue "El'structure.
December 30, 1939
Nathan Schwartz
New Yor Public Library
Photostat Division
